conclusion: A shadow is formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area behind it. The shape of the shadow depends on the shape of the object and its orientation relative to the light source.
Shadow A is cast by the lampshade and is relatively short and close to the object.
Shadow B is cast by the pastry and is relatively short and close to the object.
Shadow C is cast by the cake and is similar in size and distance from the cake as the other shadows.
Shadow D is cast by the hand and is elongated and further from the object compared to the others.

premise: When the light source moves forward, the angle at which the light hits the objects changes.
conclusion: The shadows will move backward (away from the direction the light source moved) because the light rays now have to travel a longer path to reach the ground after being blocked by the objects.

premise: The light source moves forward, changing the angle of light rays.
conclusion: Shadow A will move backward and become slightly larger.

premise: The light source moves forward, changing the angle of light rays.
conclusion: Shadow B will move backward and become slightly larger.

premise: The light source moves forward, changing the angle of light rays.
conclusion: Shadow C will move backward and become slightly larger.

premise: The light source moves forward, changing the angle of light rays.
conclusion: Shadow D will move backward and become slightly larger.

premise: As the light source gets closer to the objects by moving forward, the angle of the light rays becomes more oblique (less perpendicular).
conclusion: The shadows will get larger because the shadow spreads out more on the ground.

premise: The light source moves forward above the objects, changing the angle of light rays and their path length.
conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward (away from the new position of the light source) and increase in size.
